Multi-hop transmissions: Some incremental subgradient algorithms [4]–[6] require the node that has the latest estimate of \$x^{\ast}\$ to pass it on to a randomly and equiprobably chosen node in the network.

The main drawbacks of code-based cryptosystems is historically a large size of public key, meanwhile in recent years, propositions have been made, based on structured matrices (quasi-cyclic or dyadic) to deal with this issue [22], [4], [30].

In particular the double-circulant variation of the Stern identification scheme [22] is believed to be very hard to break, being based on the difficulty of decoding a binary code up to the Gilbert-Varshamov bound, which is not known even in the case of structured codes (like Bose–Chaudhuri–Hocquenghen (BCH) or Reed–Muller codes, for instance).
It was remarked in [22] that this problem could also be used with Stern's scheme, the proof works exactly the same.
In [22] the authors propose a variation on the scheme by taking the secret key to be a small word of the code associated to \$H\$.

The general idea of our protocol is that each of the \$t\$ signers performs by himself an instance of Stern's scheme using matrix \$H_i\$ and a null syndrome as parameters (as in the scheme's variation proposed in [22]).

Our protocol generalizes Gaborit and Girault's flavour of Stern's protocol [22] in the sense that the small weight secret codeword in their protocol is “expanded” into a vector where blocks of secret nonzero vectors (the secret key of user \$i\$) correspond to 1 in the small secret (at the \$i\$th position), whereas the blocks of zeros correspond to 0 in the small secret.
It was recently proposed in [22], to use double-circulant random matrices rather than pure random matrix for such matrices.

It is explained in [22] that this construction does not decrease the difficulty of the decoding but clearly decrease dramatically the size of the description of \$H_i\$: \$n/2\$ bits against \$n^2/2\$.

It is not known whether this problem is NP-complete or not (although the problem of decoding quasi-cyclic code in general, has been proven NP-complete in [4]), but the problem is probably as hard as the \$MD\$ problem, and on practical point of view (see [22] for details) the practical security is almost the same for best known attack that the MD problem.
Practically the author of [22] propose \$n=347\$.

context.text: A long time after, Stern proposed in [38] a zero-knowledge identification protocol based on a well-known error-correcting codes problem usually referred as the Syndrome Decoding Problem (SD in short).
In this paper, we present a generalization of Stern's identification and signature scheme [38] that we use to design new ring and threshold ring signature schemes.

This problem was used by Stern to design his identification protocol [38], but in fact a few years later a variation on this problem called the minimum distance (MD) problem was also proven to be NP-complete in [41]: Problem: (MD) Minimum Distance Instance: A binary \$(n-k) \times n\$ matrix \$H\$ and an integer \$\omega > 0\$.
This scheme was developed in 1993 (see [38]).
It is proven in [38] that this scheme is a zero-knowledge Fiat–Shamir like scheme with a probability of cheating in \$2/3\$ (rather than in \$1/2\$ for Fiat–Shamir).
In practice Stern proposed in [38] to use rate \$1/2\$ codes and \$\omega\$ just below the Gilbert-Varshamov bound associated to the code.
